See also: [Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States")

[![Image 23: Trump speaks in the West Wing briefing room with various officials standing behind him, all in formal attire and without face masks](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/White_House_Press_Briefing_%2849666120807%29.jpg/250px-White_House_Press_Briefing_%2849666120807%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:White_House_Press_Briefing_(49666120807).jpg)

Conducting a COVID-19 press briefing with members of the [White House Coronavirus Task Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House_Coronavirus_Task_Force "White House Coronavirus Task Force") on March 15, 2020

Trump initially ignored public health warnings and calls for action from health officials within his administration.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-329) Trump established the [White House Coronavirus Task Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House_Coronavirus_Task_Force "White House Coronavirus Task Force") on January 29.[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-330) On March 27, he signed into law the [CARES Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CARES_Act "CARES Act")—a $2.2 trillion bipartisan [economic stimulus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_stimulus "Economic stimulus") bill—the largest stimulus in U.S. history.[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-NY_Times_stimulus_united_senate-331)[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-AP_Trump_signs_2.2-332) After weeks of attacks to draw attention away from his slow response, Trump halted funding of the [World Health Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") in April.[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-333) In April 2020, Republican-connected groups organized [anti-lockdown protests](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protests_in_the_United_States_over_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Protests in the United States over responses to the COVID-19 pandemic") against the measures state governments were taking to combat the pandemic;[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-334)[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-335) Trump encouraged the protests on [Twitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter "Twitter"),[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-336) although the targeted states did not meet his administration's guidelines for reopening.[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-337) He repeatedly pressured federal health agencies to take actions he favored,[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-CNN-testing-pressure-338) such as approving unproven treatments.[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-339)[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-pressed-340) In October, Trump was hospitalized at [Walter Reed National Military Medical Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Reed_National_Military_Medical_Center "Walter Reed National Military Medical Center") for three days with a severe case of [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19").[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-341)

Further information: [Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_interference_in_the_2016_United_States_elections "Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections"), [Mueller special counsel investigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mueller_special_counsel_investigation "Mueller special counsel investigation"), and [Mueller report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mueller_report "Mueller report")

After he assumed office, Trump was the subject of increasing [Justice Department](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice "United States Department of Justice") and congressional scrutiny, with investigations covering his election campaign, transition, and inauguration, actions taken during his presidency, his [private businesses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Trump_Organization "The Trump Organization"), personal taxes, and [charitable foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_J._Trump_Foundation "Donald J. Trump Foundation").[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-342) There were ten federal criminal investigations, eight state and local investigations, and twelve congressional investigations.[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-343)

In July 2016, the [FBI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FBI "FBI") launched [Crossfire Hurricane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crossfire_Hurricane_(FBI_investigation) "Crossfire Hurricane (FBI investigation)"), an investigation into possible links between Russia and Trump's 2016 campaign.[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-344) After Trump fired Comey in May 2017, the FBI opened a second investigation into Trump's personal and [business dealings with Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_projects_of_Donald_Trump_in_Russia "Business projects of Donald Trump in Russia").[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-345) In January 2017, three U.S. intelligence agencies jointly stated with "high confidence" that [Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_interference_in_the_2016_United_States_elections "Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections") to favor Trump.[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-346)[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-347) Many suspicious[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-348)[links between Trump associates and Russian officials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Links_between_Trump_associates_and_Russian_officials "Links between Trump associates and Russian officials") were discovered.[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-349)[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-350)[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-351) Trump told Russian officials he was unconcerned about Russia's election interference.[[348]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-352) Crossfire Hurricane was later transferred to [Robert Mueller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Mueller "Robert Mueller")'s [special counsel investigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mueller_special_counsel_investigation "Mueller special counsel investigation");[[349]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-353) the investigation into Trump's ties to Russia was ended by Deputy Attorney General [Rod Rosenstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_Rosenstein "Rod Rosenstein") after he told the FBI that Mueller would pursue the matter.[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-never-354)[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-355) At the request of Rosenstein, the Mueller investigation examined criminal matters "in connection with Russia's 2016 election interference".[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-never-354) Mueller submitted [his final report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mueller_report "Mueller report") in March 2019.[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-356) The report found that Russia did interfere in 2016 to favor Trump[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-357) and that Trump and his campaign welcomed and encouraged the effort,[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-358)[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-359)[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-360) but that the evidence "did not establish" that Trump campaign members conspired or coordinated with Russia.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-361)[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-takeaways-362) Trump claimed the report exonerated him despite Mueller writing that it did not.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-363) The report also detailed potential obstruction of justice by Trump but "did not draw ultimate conclusions"[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-364)[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-365) and left the decision to charge the laws to Congress.[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-LM-366)

In April 2019, the [House Oversight Committee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_Oversight_Committee "House Oversight Committee") issued [subpoenas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subpoena "Subpoena") seeking financial details from Trump's banks, Deutsche Bank and [Capital One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_One "Capital One"), and his accounting firm, [Mazars USA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazars_USA "Mazars USA"). He sued the banks, Mazars, and committee chair [Elijah Cummings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elijah_Cummings "Elijah Cummings") to prevent the disclosures.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-367) In May, two judges ruled that both Mazars and the banks must comply with the subpoenas;[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-368)[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-369)[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-370) Trump's attorneys appealed.[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-371) In September 2022, Trump and the committee agreed to a settlement regarding Mazars, and the firm began turning over documents.[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-372)

Main articles: [First impeachment of Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_impeachment_of_Donald_Trump "First impeachment of Donald Trump") and [Second impeachment of Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_impeachment_of_Donald_Trump "Second impeachment of Donald Trump")

[![Image 24](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/President_Trump_Delivers_Remarks_%2849498772251%29.jpg/250px-President_Trump_Delivers_Remarks_%2849498772251%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:President_Trump_Delivers_Remarks_(49498772251).jpg)

Displaying the headline "Trump acquitted" in 2020

Trump was [impeached](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment_in_the_United_States "Impeachment in the United States") twice by the House of Representatives, though acquitted by the Senate on both occasions. The [first impeachment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_impeachment_of_Donald_Trump "First impeachment of Donald Trump") arose from a whistleblower complaint that in July 2019 Trump [had pressured](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Trump%E2%80%93Ukraine_scandal "2019 Trump–Ukraine scandal") Ukrainian president [Volodymyr Zelenskyy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy "Volodymyr Zelenskyy") to investigate Joe and Hunter Biden,[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-undermine-373) in an attempt to gain an advantage in the [2020 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election").[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-374) In December 2019, the House voted to impeach Trump for [abuse of power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abuse_of_power "Abuse of power") and [obstruction of Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstruction_of_Congress "Obstruction of Congress"),[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-375) and the Senate acquitted him in February 2020.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-376)

The [second impeachment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_impeachment_of_Donald_Trump "Second impeachment of Donald Trump") came after the January 6 Capitol attack, for which the House charged Trump with [incitement of insurrection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incitement_of_insurrection "Incitement of insurrection") on January 13, 2021.[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-SecondImpeachment-377) Trump left office on January 20, and was acquitted on February 13. Seven Republican senators voted for conviction.[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-378)

Trump filed to run for reelection only a few hours after becoming president in 2017.[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-379) He held his first reelection rally less than a month after taking office[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-380) and officially became the [Republican nominee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Republican_Party_presidential_primaries "2020 Republican Party presidential primaries") in August 2020.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-381) Trump's campaign focused on crime, claiming that cities would descend into lawlessness if Democratic nominee Joe Biden won.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-382) He repeatedly misrepresented Biden's positions[[379]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-383)[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-384) and appealed to racism.[[381]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-385) Starting in early 2020, Trump sowed doubts about the election, claiming without evidence that it would be rigged and that widespread use of mail balloting would produce massive election fraud.[[382]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-386)[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-387) He [blocked funding for the U.S. Postal Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_Postal_Service_crisis "2020 United States Postal Service crisis"), saying he wanted to prevent any increase in voting by mail.[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-388) He repeatedly refused to say whether he would accept the results if he lost and commit to a [peaceful transition of power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peaceful_transition_of_power "Peaceful transition of power").[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-389)[[386]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-390)

Further information: [Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election "Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election") and [2020–21 United States election protests](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020%E2%80%9321_United_States_election_protests "2020–21 United States election protests")

Joe Biden won the November 2020 election, receiving 81.3 million votes (51.3 percent) to Trump's 74.2 million (46.8 percent)[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-vote1-391)[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-vote2-392) and 306 electoral votes to Trump's 232,[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-formalize-393) with the [Electoral College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College "United States Electoral College") formalizing Biden's victory on December 14.[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-formalize-393) Trump declared victory before the results were known on the morning after the election.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-394) Days later, when Biden was projected the winner, Trump baselessly alleged election fraud.[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-395) As part of [an effort to overturn the results](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election "Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election"), Trump and his allies filed many [lawsuits challenging the results](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-election_lawsuits_related_to_the_2020_U.S._presidential_election "Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election"), which were rejected by at least 86 judges in both state and federal courts for having no factual or legal basis.[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-396)[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-397)

Trump's allegations were also refuted by state election officials,[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-398) and the Supreme Court declined to hear [a case asking it to overturn the results](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_v._Pennsylvania "Texas v. Pennsylvania") in four states won by Biden.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-399) Trump repeatedly sought help to overturn the results, personally pressuring Republican local and state office-holders,[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-amyG-400) Republican legislators,[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-pressure-401) the Justice Department,[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-402) and Vice President Pence,[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-403) urging actions such as [replacing presidential electors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trump_fake_electors_plot "Trump fake electors plot"),[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-pressure-401) or that Georgia officials ["find" votes and announce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trump%E2%80%93Raffensperger_phone_call "Trump–Raffensperger phone call") a "recalculated" result.[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-amyG-400) He initially blocked government officials from cooperating in [Biden's presidential transition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_transition_of_Joe_Biden "Presidential transition of Joe Biden").[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-404)[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-405) After three weeks, the administrator of the [General Services Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Services_Administration "General Services Administration") declared Biden the "apparent winner" of the election, allowing the disbursement of transition resources to his team.[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-406) Trump did not attend [Biden's inauguration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biden%27s_inauguration "Biden's inauguration") on January 20.[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-407)

Main article: [January 6 United States Capitol attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack "January 6 United States Capitol attack")

In December 2020, reports emerged that U.S. military leaders were on high alert, and ranking officers had discussed what to do if Trump declared [martial law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martial_law "Martial law").[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-408) CIA director [Gina Haspel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gina_Haspel "Gina Haspel") and Army general [Mark Milley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Milley "Mark Milley"), chairman of the [Joint Chiefs of Staff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff "Joint Chiefs of Staff"), grew concerned that Trump might attempt a [coup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coup "Coup") or military action against China or Iran.[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-409)[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-410) Milley insisted that he be consulted about any military orders from Trump, including the use of nuclear weapons.[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-411)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-412)

[![Image 25](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09254-2_%2850820534063%29_%28retouched%29.jpg/250px-2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09254-2_%2850820534063%29_%28retouched%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09254-2_(50820534063)_(retouched).jpg)

A crowd of Trump supporters during the attack

At noon on January 6, 2021, while [Congress was certifying the presidential election results](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_United_States_Electoral_College_vote_count "2021 United States Electoral College vote count") in the [U.S. Capitol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Capitol "U.S. Capitol"), Trump held [a rally at the nearby Ellipse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_Trump_rally "January 6 Trump rally"). Speaking from behind a glass barrier,[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-413) he called for the election to be overturned and urged his supporters to "fight like hell" and "take back our country" by marching to the Capitol.[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-414) His supporters then [formed a mob that broke into the building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack "January 6 United States Capitol attack"), disrupting certification and causing the evacuation of Congress.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-415) During the attack, Trump posted on social media but did not ask the rioters to disperse. In a [tweet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tweet_(social_media) "Tweet (social media)") at 6 p.m., he told them to "go home with love & in peace", called them "great patriots", and restated that he had won the election.[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-416) Congress later reconvened and confirmed Biden's victory in the early hours of January 7.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-417)

More than 140 police officers were injured, and five people died during or after the attack.[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-418)[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-419) The event has been described as an attempted [self-coup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-coup "Self-coup") by Trump.[[e]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-423)

triples.statement: General Milley insisted on being consulted about any military orders from Trump, including those involving the use of nuclear weapons.

section_body: Upon leaving the White House, Trump began living at Mar-a-Lago, establishing an office there as provided for by the [Former Presidents Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Former_Presidents_Act "Former Presidents Act").[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-424) His continuing [false claims concerning the 2020 election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_lie#Donald_Trump's_false_claims_of_a_stolen_election "Big lie") were commonly referred to as the "[big lie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_lie "Big lie")" by his critics, although in May 2021, he and many of his supporters began using the term to refer to the election itself.[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-425)[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-key2-426) The Republican Party used his false claims about the election to justify [imposing new voting restrictions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_efforts_to_restrict_voting_following_the_2020_presidential_election "Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 presidential election") in its favor.[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-427)[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-428)[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-429) He continued to pressure state legislators to overturn the election.[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-430) Unlike other former presidents, Trump continued to dominate his party; a 2022 profile in _The New York Times_ described him as a modern [party boss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_boss "Party boss").[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-PB2-431) He continued fundraising, raising a [war chest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_chest "War chest") containing more than twice that of the Republican Party, and profited from fundraisers many Republican candidates held at Mar-a-Lago. Much of his focus was on party governance and installing in key posts officials loyal to him.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-PB2-431) In the [2022 midterm elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_midterm_elections "2022 midterm elections"), he endorsed over 200 candidates for various offices.[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-432) In February 2021, he registered a new company, [Trump Media & Technology Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trump_Media_%26_Technology_Group "Trump Media & Technology Group") (TMTG), for providing "social networking services" to U.S. customers.[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-433)[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-434) In March 2024, TMTG merged with [special-purpose acquisition company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special-purpose_acquisition_company "Special-purpose acquisition company")[Digital World Acquisition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_World_Acquisition_Corp. "Digital World Acquisition Corp.") and became a [public company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_company "Public company").[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-435) In February 2022, TMTG launched [Truth Social](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth_Social "Truth Social"), a social media platform.[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-436)

Jean Carroll") accused Trump of raping her in the 1990s and [sued him for defamation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._Jean_Carroll_v._Donald_J._Trump "E. Jean Carroll v. Donald J. Trump") over his denial.[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-437) Carroll sued him again in 2022 for [battery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_(crime) "Battery (crime)") and further defamation.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-438) He was [found liable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_liability "Legal liability") for sexual abuse and defamation and ordered to pay $5 million in one case[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-439) and $83.3 million in the other.[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-uphold-440) Federal appeals courts upheld both findings and awards in December 2024 and September 2025, respectively.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-441)[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-uphold-440)

In 2022, [New York filed a civil lawsuit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_business_fraud_lawsuit_against_the_Trump_Organization "New York business fraud lawsuit against the Trump Organization") against Trump accusing him of inflating the Trump Organization's value to gain an advantage with lenders and banks.[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-442)[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-TF-443) He was found liable and ordered to pay nearly $355 million plus interest.[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-TF-443) In August 2025, the appeals court upheld his liability and nonmonetary penalties, but voided the monetary penalty as excessive.[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-444)

Classified intelligence material found during search of Mar-a-Lago

In connection with Trump's efforts to overturn the 2020 election and his involvement in the January 6 attack, in December 2022 the [U.S. House committee on the attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Select_Committee_on_the_January_6_Attack "United States House Select Committee on the January 6 Attack") recommended criminal charges against him for [obstructing an official proceeding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstructing_an_official_proceeding "Obstructing an official proceeding"), [conspiracy to defraud the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conspiracy_to_defraud_the_United_States "Conspiracy to defraud the United States"), and inciting or assisting an insurrection.[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-445) In August 2023, a grand jury in [Fulton County, Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fulton_County,_Georgia "Fulton County, Georgia"), indicted him on [13 charges, including racketeering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_election_racketeering_prosecution "Georgia election racketeering prosecution"), for his efforts to subvert the 2020 election in the state.[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-446)[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-447) The case was dismissed in November 2025 after the new prosecutor declined to pursue the charges.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-448)

In January 2022, the [National Archives and Records Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Archives_and_Records_Administration "National Archives and Records Administration") retrieved 15 boxes of documents Trump had taken to Mar-a-Lago after leaving the White House, some of which were classified.[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-cnn-tl222-449) In the ensuing Justice Department investigation, officials retrieved more classified documents from his lawyers.[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-cnn-tl222-449) On August 8, 2022, [FBI agents searched Mar-a-Lago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FBI_search_of_Mar-a-Lago "FBI search of Mar-a-Lago") for illegally held documents, including those in breach of the [Espionage Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Espionage_Act "Espionage Act"), collecting 11 sets of classified documents, some marked top secret.[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-bddj0812222-450)[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-NYT-20220812222-451) A [federal grand jury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_grand_jury "Federal grand jury") constituted by Special Counsel [Jack Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Smith_(lawyer) "Jack Smith (lawyer)") indicted Trump in June 2023 on 31 counts of "willfully retaining national defense information" under the [Espionage Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Espionage_Act "Espionage Act"), among other charges.[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-cnn-tl222-449)[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-452)[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-453) Trump pleaded not guilty.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-454) In July 2024, judge [Aileen Cannon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aileen_Cannon "Aileen Cannon") dismissed [the case](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_(classified_documents_case) "Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (classified documents case)"), ruling Smith's appointment as special prosecutor was unconstitutional.[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-CD2-455) After his reelection, the [2020 election obstruction case](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_(election_obstruction_case) "Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (election obstruction case)") and the classified documents case were dismissed [without prejudice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prejudice_(legal_term)#With_prejudice_and_without_prejudice "Prejudice (legal term)") due to Justice Department policy against prosecuting sitting presidents.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-dismiss2-456)

In May 2024, Trump [was convicted on 34 felony counts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_New_York "Prosecution of Donald Trump in New York") of [falsifying business records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falsifying_business_records "Falsifying business records").[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-conv-457) The case stemmed from evidence that he booked [Michael Cohen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Cohen_(lawyer) "Michael Cohen (lawyer)")'s hush-money payments to adult film actress [Stormy Daniels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stormy_Daniels "Stormy Daniels") as business expenses to cover up his alleged 2006–2007 affair with Daniels during the 2016 election.[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-conv-457)[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-458) On January 10, 2025, the judge gave Trump a no-penalty sentence known as an unconditional discharge, saying that punitive requirements would have interfered with presidential immunity.[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-uds-459)

Further information: [Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign "Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign"), [2024 Republican Party presidential primaries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_presidential_primaries "2024 Republican Party presidential primaries"), and [Second presidential transition of Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_presidential_transition_of_Donald_Trump "Second presidential transition of Donald Trump")

In November 2022, Trump announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election and created a fundraising account.[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-460)[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-461) In March 2023, the campaign began diverting ten percent of the donations to his [leadership PAC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leadership_PAC "Leadership PAC"). His campaign had paid $100 million towards his legal bills by March 2024.[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-462)[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-463)

During the campaign, Trump made increasingly violent and authoritarian statements.[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-464) He said that he would weaponize the FBI and the Justice Department against his political opponents[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-465)[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-466) and use the military to target Democratic politicians and those that did not support his candidacy.[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-467)[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Lerer_10152024-468) He used harsher and more dehumanizing anti-immigrant rhetoric than during his presidency.[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-469) His rhetoric, calling his political opponents "the enemy", vermin, and fascists, has been described by some historians and scholars as authoritarian, [fascist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_and_fascism "Donald Trump and fascism"),[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-470) and unlike anything a political candidate has ever said in American history.[[466]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-NYMag_Never_Sounded_Like_This-471)[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Lerer_10152024-468)[[467]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Applebaum18-472)[Age and health concerns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_and_health_concerns_about_Donald_Trump "Age and health concerns about Donald Trump") also arose during the campaign, with several medical experts highlighting an increase in rambling, [tangential speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangential_speech "Tangential speech") and [behavioral disinhibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinhibition "Disinhibition").[[468]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-473)

Trump mentioned "rigged election" and "election interference" earlier and more frequently than in the 2016 and 2020 campaigns and refused to commit to accepting the 2024 election results.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-474)[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-NYTDoubts-475) Analysts for _The New York Times_ described this as an intensification of his "heads I win; tails you cheated" rhetorical strategy; the newspaper stated that the claim of a rigged election had become the backbone of the campaign.[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-NYTDoubts-475)

On July 13, 2024, Trump was shot in the ear in [an assassination attempt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Donald_Trump_in_Pennsylvania "Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Pennsylvania") at a campaign rally in [Butler Township, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler_Township,_Butler_County,_Pennsylvania "Butler Township, Butler County, Pennsylvania").[[471]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Browne-2024-476)[[472]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-477)[[473]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-478) Two days later, the [2024 Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Republican_National_Convention "2024 Republican National Convention") nominated him as their presidential candidate.[[474]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-479) In September he was targeted but unharmed in [an assassination attempt in Florida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Donald_Trump_in_Florida "Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Florida").[[475]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-480) Trump won the election in November 2024 with 312 electoral votes to incumbent vice president Kamala Harris's 226.[[476]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-481) He also won the popular vote with 49.8% to Harris's 48.3%.[[477]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-482) His victory in 2024 was in large part due to the [2021–2023 inflation surge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge "2021–2023 inflation surge").[[478]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Global_Politics-483)[[479]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-484) Several outlets described his reelection as an extraordinary comeback.[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-485)[[481]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-486)

See also: [First 100 days of the second Trump presidency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_100_days_of_the_second_Trump_presidency "First 100 days of the second Trump presidency")

More than a month before the 100-day mark of Trump's second term, he had [issued more executive orders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_executive_orders_in_the_second_Trump_presidency "List of executive orders in the second Trump presidency") than any other U.S. president's first 100 days.[[486]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-491) Many of these tested his legal authority, and drew immediate legal action.[[487]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-492) Four days into his second term, analysis conducted by _[Time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time\_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")_ found that nearly two-thirds of his executive actions "mirror or partially mirror" proposals from [Project 2025](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_2025 "Project 2025").[[488]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-493) In his first weeks, several of his actions ignored or violated federal laws, regulations, and the Constitution according to American legal scholars.[[489]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-494)[[490]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-495)[[491]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-496) His orders and actions were challenged by over 300 lawsuits nationwide. By mid-November, 149 had been blocked or partially blocked, 102 left in effect, and 107 were pending.[[492]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-497)

Following legal setbacks, Trump increased his criticism of the judiciary and called for impeachment of federal judges who ruled against him.[[493]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-498) By mid-July, a _[Washington Post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington\_Post "Washington Post")_ analysis found he defied judges and the courts in roughly one third of all cases against him, actions which were described by legal experts as unprecedented for any presidential administration.[[494]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-499)

Multiple analyses conducted by academic scholars and _[The New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_New\_York\_Times "The New York Times")_ found that both Republican and Democratic judicial appointees have found numerous constitutional and statutory flaws with Trump administration policies.[[495]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-500) His administration asserted a constitutional right to ignore federal law in its justification of several actions such as in his refusal to enforce a [federal ban on TikTok](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protecting_Americans_from_Foreign_Adversary_Controlled_Applications_Act "Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act"), with legal experts describing it as claiming a "constitutional power to immunize private parties to commit otherwise illegal acts with impunity".[[496]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-501)[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-502)[[498]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-503)

Trump's second presidency was described as having fewer guardrails against conflicts of interest than his first,[[499]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Yourish_2025-504) and breaking with decades of ethical norms.[[500]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-505) He maintained a publicly traded company in [Trump Media & Technology Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trump_Media_%26_Technology_Group "Trump Media & Technology Group"), and diversified it into financial services.[[501]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-506) He pursued new overseas real estate deals involving state-affiliated entities, and had several branding and licensing deals selling Trump-branded merchandise.[[499]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Yourish_2025-504) He profited from events held at his hotels and golf courses and did not place his assets in a blind trust, as previous presidents had done.[[502]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Schouten_1232025-507) In August 2025, Trump's mandatory disclosure of investment showed that, since taking office, he had made 690 purchases of municipal bonds and corporate stock totaling at least $103.7 million. Included was stock in companies affected by his changes to federal policies.[[503]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-508)

Trump launched, promoted, and personally benefited from [two cryptocurrency tokens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Trump_Organization#Other_ventures_and_investments "The Trump Organization") ("meme coins"), [$Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/$Trump "$Trump") and $Melania.[[504]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Weissert_1222025-509)[[505]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-510) He also directly benefited from his family's cryptocurrency company [World Liberty Financial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Liberty_Financial "World Liberty Financial"), which engaged in an unprecedented mixing of private enterprise and government policy.[[506]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Lipton_04292025-511)

In July 2025, the Trump administration accepted a [$400 million luxury jet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N7478D "N7478D") from Qatar. The aircraft will serve as [Air Force One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_Force_One "Air Force One") until the end of his second term, when it will be transferred to his presidential library. The retrofitting as Air Force One is estimated to cost up to $1 billion.[[507]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-512)

Main article: [2025 United States federal mass layoffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_United_States_federal_mass_layoffs "2025 United States federal mass layoffs")

Trump implemented a hiring freeze across the federal government and ordered telework of federal employees to be discontinued within 30 days.[[508]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-513)[[509]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-upend-514) He ordered a review of many career civil service positions with the intention of [reclassifying them into at-will positions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Policy/Career_appointment "Policy/Career appointment") without job protections.[[509]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-upend-514)[[510]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-515)[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-516) He initiated mass job terminations of federal employees,[[512]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Collinson-517) which were described by legal experts as unprecedented or in violation of federal law,[[513]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-518) with the intent of replacing them with workers more aligned with his agenda.[[514]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-519) By late February, the administration had fired more than 30,000 people.[[515]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-520) To facilitate further terminations, it adopted a novel legal interpretation that vastly expands the range of departments and agencies considered as having national security for their primary During his second presidency, the Trump administration took a series of actions using the government to target political opponents and [civil society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_society "Civil society"). His actions were described by the media as part of his promised "retribution" and "revenge" campaign, within the context of a strongly personalist and leader-centered conception of He threatened, signed executive actions, and ordered investigations into his political opponents, critics, and organizations aligned with the Democratic Party.[[532]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-537) He ended the post-[Watergate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watergate_scandal "Watergate scandal") norm of [Justice his political enemies.[[533]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-538)[[534]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-539) He continued filing personal lawsuits against in settlements in a "cultural crackdown" against a variety of institutions that largely chose to settle rather than fight back.[[536]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-541)[[537]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-542) Trump's actions against civil society were described by hundreds Main articles: [Domestic policy of the second Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_policy_of_the_second_Trump_administration "Domestic policy of the second Trump administration"), [Economic policy of the second Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_policy_of_the_second_Trump_administration "Economic policy of the second Trump administration"), [Education policy of the second Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education_policy_of_the_second_Trump_administration "Education policy of the second Trump administration"), [Science policy of the second Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_policy_of_the_second_Trump_administration "Science policy of the second Trump administration"), and [Persecution of transgender people under the second Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persecution_of_transgender_people_under_the_second_Trump_administration "Persecution of transgender people under the second Trump administration")

Trump inherited a resilient economy from the Biden administration, with increasing economic growth, low unemployment, and declining inflation.[[545]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-550) He ordered agencies to stop enforcement of disfavored rules in an attempt at large-scale deregulation that legal experts described as illegal and contrary to decades of federal law.[[546]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-551)[[547]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-552) He sought greater government control over private businesses and shifted away from traditional conservative [free market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_market "Free market") orthodoxy,[[548]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-553) engaging in [state capitalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_capitalism "State capitalism") by taking direct government equity stakes in multiple U.S. corporations.[[549]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-554)[[550]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Economist_08132025-555)[[551]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-556)

Trump [canceled and paused federal grants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_United_States_federal_government_grant_pause "2025 United States federal government grant pause") and made large cuts to scientific research,[[552]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-557) several of which were found by judges and the [Government Accountability Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Accountability_Office "Government Accountability Office") as being illegal and unconstitutional.[[553]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-558)[[554]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-559) Trump and his administration's [Make America Healthy Again](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Make_America_Healthy_Again "Make America Healthy Again") agenda promoted [anti-science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-science "Anti-science") and [anti-vaccine activism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-vaccine_activism "Anti-vaccine activism"), resulting in a resurgence of whooping cough and measles.[[555]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-560)[[556]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-561)

He promoted [climate change denial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_denial "Climate change denial") and misinformation,[[557]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-562) appointed oil, gas, and chemical lobbyists to the [United States Environmental Protection Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency "United States Environmental Protection Agency") (EPA) to reverse climate regulations and pollution controls,[[558]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-563) and by October 2025 had cancelled $7.6 billion in funding for clean energy projects approved by the previous administration.[[559]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-564)

Trump relied on declaring national emergencies to justify hundreds of actions and bypass congressional approval or regulatory review.[[560]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-565) For instance, he declared a national energy emergency, allowing the suspension of environmental regulations, loosening the rules for fossil fuel extraction and limiting renewable energy projects.[[561]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-566)[[562]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-567) Trump withdrew the U.S. from the [Paris Agreement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris_Agreement "Paris Agreement") on climate change during his first presidency, [Biden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_of_Joe_Biden "Presidency of Joe Biden") reentered the agreement in 2021, and Trump again withdrew from the agreement during his second presidency.[[563]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-568)

Dismantling government agencies enforcing the laws against political corruption and white-collar fraud,[[564]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-569) Trump reduced the Department of Justice's [Public Integrity Section](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Integrity_Section "Public Integrity Section") from 30 to five lawyers,[[565]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-570)[[566]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-defang-571) dismissed 17 independent [inspectors general](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inspector_general#United_States "Inspector general") at government agencies[[567]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-572) and 12 members of independent oversight boards and watchdog agencies,[[568]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-573) and disbanded the squad in the FBI's Washington field office that investigated allegations of fraud and corruption against government officials and members of Congress.[[569]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-squad-574)[[570]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-575) He pardoned or dropped charges against officials accused of corruption.[[569]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-squad-574)

Trump attributed societal problems to [diversity, equity, and inclusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diversity,_equity,_and_inclusion "Diversity, equity, and inclusion") (DEI) initiatives and [wokeness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woke#United_States "Woke").[[571]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Green250203-576) Equating diversity with incompetence,[[571]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Green250203-576) he reversed pro-diversity policies in the federal government.[[572]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-577)[[573]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-578) He sought to remake civil society to his preferences by executive order.[[574]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-579)[[575]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-APfirms-580) On DEI and antisemitism grounds, he threatened cultural institutions[[576]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-581) and sixty universities,[[577]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-WSJed-582) and forced law firms to capitulate to his political agenda.[[575]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-APfirms-580)

Trump expanded the domestic use of the military and ordered [military deployments to several Democratic Party-led cities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_deployment_of_federal_forces_in_the_United_States "2025 deployment of federal forces in the United States"), and threatened to expand his deployments further.[[578]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-583)[[579]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-584) Trump had crews [demolish the White House's East Wing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Wing#Demolition "East Wing") in October 2025 to make room for a [White House State Ballroom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House_State_Ballroom "White House State Ballroom"), which is planned to be nearly twice the size of the White House.[[580]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-585)[[581]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-586)

Through [a series of executive orders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persecution_of_transgender_people_under_the_second_Trump_administration#Executive_Orders "Persecution of transgender people under the second Trump administration") and other actions, Trump banned trans people from the military,[[582]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-587) restricted or defunded gender-affirming healthcare, opposed [inclusive language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_language "Inclusive language"),[[583]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-588) censored research and education materials,[[584]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-589) and targeted schools, universities, and cultural institutions accused of promoting what his government calls "gender ideology",[[585]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-npr-ideology-590) barred transgender athletes from sports, and required US passports to state transgender people's sex assigned at birth.[[586]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-591)

section_body: In July 2025, Trump signed the [One Big Beautiful Bill Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Big_Beautiful_Bill_Act "One Big Beautiful Bill Act") into law. The bill made the temporary tax cuts of the 2017 [Tax Cuts and Jobs Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_Cuts_and_Jobs_Act "Tax Cuts and Jobs Act") permanent and added additional tax deductions for a total of around $4.5 trillion, mostly benefiting the highest income brackets and costing people in the lowest income bracket $1,600 per year. It increased funding for national defense, deportations, the border wall, and Trump's proposed [Golden Dome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Dome_(missile_defense_system) "Golden Dome (missile defense system)") missile defense system. It removed tax credits for renewable energy sources such as wind and solar power and for buyers of electric vehicles. The bill cut funding for [Medicaid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medicaid "Medicaid") and [SNAP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supplemental_Nutrition_Assistance_Program "Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program") and added additional work requirements for eligibility and a $35 co-payment for some Medicaid services; the cuts and additional requirements will take effect after the 2026 general election. The bill was projected by the [Congressional Budget Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office "Congressional Budget Office") to increase the budget deficit by $3.4 trillion by 2034, cause 11.8 million people to lose Medicaid coverage, and eliminate SNAP benefits for three million people.[[587]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-592)[[588]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-593)

Further information: [Mexico–United States border crisis §Second Trump administration (2025–present)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border_crisis#Second_Trump_administration_(2025%E2%80%93present) "Mexico–United States border crisis"), and [Mexico–United States border wall §Second Trump administration (2025–present)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border_wall#Second_Trump_administration_(2025%E2%80%93present) "Mexico–United States border wall")

In his first days in office, Trump instructed Border Patrol agents to summarily deport [illegal immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States "Illegal immigration to the United States") crossing the border and disabled the [CBP One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBP_One "CBP One") app that was being used to schedule border crossings. He resumed the [remain in Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remain_in_Mexico "Remain in Mexico") policy, designated drug cartels as terrorist groups, and ordered construction to be resumed on a border wall.[[589]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-594)[[590]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Cbsjan28-595) Trump also revoked the parole status of immigrants who entered the U.S. under CBP One and ended [humanitarian parole for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parole_for_Cubans,_Haitians,_Nicaraguans,_and_Venezuelans "Parole for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans").[[590]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Cbsjan28-595) In March, he used the [Alien Enemies Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Enemies_Act "Alien Enemies Act") of 1798 to [imprison illegal immigrants without trial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/March_2025_American_deportations_of_Venezuelans "March 2025 American deportations of Venezuelans") at the [Terrorism Confinement Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrorism_Confinement_Center "Terrorism Confinement Center") in El Salvador.[[591]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-596)[Trump targeted activists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Activist_deportations_in_the_second_Trump_presidency "Activist deportations in the second Trump presidency"), legal immigrants, tourists, and students with visas who expressed criticism of his policies or pro-Palestinian advocacy.[[592]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-597) Several [American citizens were detained and deported](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detention_and_deportation_of_American_citizens_in_the_second_Trump_administration "Detention and deportation of American citizens in the second Trump administration").[[593]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-598)

Main article: [Foreign policy of the second Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_second_Trump_administration "Foreign policy of the second Trump administration")

Further information: [Tariffs in the second Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration "Tariffs in the second Trump administration"), [China–United States trade war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_trade_war "China–United States trade war"), [2025 United States trade war with Canada and Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_United_States_trade_war_with_Canada_and_Mexico "2025 United States trade war with Canada and Mexico"), and [American expansionism under Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_expansionism_under_Donald_Trump "American expansionism under Donald Trump")

His administration favored [hard power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hard_power "Hard power") to achieve its [America First](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/America_First "America First") foreign policy goals,[[594]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-599) and dismantled or withdrew support from domestic and international organizations dedicated to advancing American [soft power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_power "Soft power").[[595]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-600)[[596]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-601) The moves were described as ceding American global influence and creating a void filled by [Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia "Russia") and [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China "China").[[597]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-602)[[f]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-604) Trump's relations with allies were transactional and ranged from indifference to hostility, including threats of annexation.[[599]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-605)[[600]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-606)

Meeting with Zelenskyy, February 2025

In February 2025, Trump and Vice President Vance [berated Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Trump%E2%80%93Zelenskyy_Oval_Office_meeting "2025 Trump–Zelenskyy Oval Office meeting") in a highly contentious televised meeting. Media outlets described it as an unprecedented public confrontation between an American president and a foreign [head of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state").[[601]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Liptak_20250228-607)[[602]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-608)

Trump and his incoming administration helped broker [a Gaza war ceasefire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_2025_Gaza_war_ceasefire "January 2025 Gaza war ceasefire") alongside the Biden administration, enacted a day prior to his inauguration.[[603]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-609)[[604]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-610)[[605]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-credit-611) In March, [Israel broke the ceasefire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/March_2025_Israeli_attacks_on_the_Gaza_Strip "March 2025 Israeli attacks on the Gaza Strip").[[605]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-credit-611) On October 9, 2025, Israel and Hamas signed an agreement to cease fire and exchange Israeli hostages for Palestinian prisoners as part of the [first phase of Trump's initiative](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_peace_plan "Gaza peace plan") to end the [Gaza war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war").[[606]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-612)

Trump's economic policies have been described as [protectionist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protectionism_in_the_United_States "Protectionism in the United States"),[[607]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-613) with Trump imposing tariffs on most countries, including large tariffs on major trading partners China, Canada, and Mexico.[[608]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-614) He started a global [trade war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_war "Trade war"), imposing tariffs at the highest level since the 1930 [Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoot%E2%80%93Hawley_Tariff_Act "Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act") at the onset of the [Great Depression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression").[[609]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-615)[[610]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-616) Economists argued that the administration misunderstood the relationship between [trade deficits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balance_of_trade "Balance of trade") and tariffs, using flawed assumptions.[[611]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-617) Trump suspended American financial contributions to the [World Trade Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Organization "World Trade Organization").[[612]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-618)

In his second term, Trump selected [cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_cabinet_of_Donald_Trump "Second cabinet of Donald Trump") members with personal loyalty to him,[[613]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-619)[[614]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-focus-620) with the "focus on loyalty over subject-matter expertise".[[614]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-focus-620) In February 2025, the White House stated that [Elon Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk") was a [special government employee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_government_employee "Special government employee").[[615]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-musk-621) Trump gave Musk's [Department of Government Efficiency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Department_of_Government_Efficiency "Department of Government Efficiency") (DOGE) access to many federal government agencies.[[615]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-musk-621) Musk's teams operated in eighteen departments and agencies in the administration's first month,[[616]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-622) including in the Treasury Department's $5 trillion payment system,[[617]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-623) the [Small Business Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Small_Business_Administration "Small Business Administration"), the [Office of Personnel Management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_Personnel_Management "Office of Personnel Management"), and the [General Services Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Services_Administration "General Services Administration").[[618]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-624)

Many of Trump's comments and actions have been characterized as racist.[[649]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-656) In a 2018 national poll, about half of respondents said he is racist; a greater proportion believed that he emboldened racists.[[650]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-657) Several studies and surveys found that racist attitudes fueled his political ascent and were more important than economic factors in determining the allegiance of Trump voters.[[651]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-658) Racist and [Islamophobic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamophobic "Islamophobic") attitudes are strong indicators of support for Trump.[[652]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-FOOTNOTELajevardiOskooii2018-659) He has been accused of racism for insisting a group of five black and Latino teenagers were guilty of raping a white woman in the 1989 [Central Park jogger case](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Park_jogger_case "Central Park jogger case"), even after they were exonerated in 2002.[[653]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-660)

In 2011, Trump became the leading proponent of the racist ["birther" conspiracy theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barack_Obama_citizenship_conspiracy_theories "Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories") that Barack Obama, the first black U.S. president, was not born in the United States.[[654]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-661) He claimed credit for pressuring the government to publish Obama's birth certificate, which he considered fraudulent.[[655]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-662) In September 2016, he acknowledged that Obama was born in the U.S.,[[656]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-663) though he reportedly expressed birther views privately in 2017.[[657]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-664) During the 2024 presidential campaign, he made false attacks against the racial identity of his opponent, Kamala Harris, that were described as reminiscent of the birther conspiracy theory.[[658]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-665) His 2024 campaign made extensive use of [dehumanizing language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dehumanization "Dehumanization") and [racial stereotypes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_stereotype "Ethnic stereotype").[[659]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-666) In 2025, he promoted false claims of [white genocide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_genocide "White genocide") in South Africa[[660]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-667) and created the [White South African refugee program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_South_African_refugee_program "White South African refugee program").[[661]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-668)

Trump has a history of belittling women when speaking to the media and on social media.[[662]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-FOOTNOTERotheCollins2019-669)[[663]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Shear-670) He made lewd comments, disparaged women's physical appearances, and referred to them using derogatory epithets.[[663]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Shear-670) As of 2020, 26 women have publicly [accused him of sexual misconduct](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_sexual_misconduct_allegations "Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations"), including rape, kissing without consent, groping, looking under women's skirts, and walking in on naked teenage pageant contestants. He has denied the allegations.[[664]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-no26-671) In October 2016, a 2005 "[hot mic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_mic "Hot mic")" recording surfaced in which [he bragged](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_Access_Hollywood_tape "Donald Trump Access Hollywood tape") about kissing and groping women without their consent, saying that, "when you're a star, they let you do it. You can do anything. ... Grab 'em by the [pussy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pussy#Female_genitalia "Pussy")."[[665]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-672) He characterized the comments as "locker-room talk".[[666]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-673)[[667]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-674) The incident's widespread media exposure led to his first public apology, videotaped during his 2016 presidential campaign.[[668]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-675)

Trump has been identified as a key figure in increasing political violence in the U.S., both for and against him.[[669]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-676)[[670]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-FOOTNOTENacosShapiroBloch-Elkon2020-677)[[671]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPiazzaVan_Doren2022-678) He is described as embracing extremism, [conspiracy theories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_conspiracy_theories_promoted_by_Donald_Trump "List of conspiracy theories promoted by Donald Trump") such as [Q-Anon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-Anon "Q-Anon"), and far-right [militia movements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_militia_movement "American militia movement") to a greater extent than any modern American president,[[624]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-Baker_07272025-630)[[672]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-679) and engaging in [stochastic terrorism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_terrorism "Stochastic terrorism").[[673]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-680)

Research suggests that Trump's rhetoric is associated with an increased incidence of hate crimes,[[674]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-681)[[675]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-682) and that he has an emboldening effect on expressing prejudicial attitudes due to his normalization of explicit racial rhetoric.[[676]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStephens-Dougan2021306-683) During his 2016 campaign, he urged or praised physical attacks against protesters or reporters.[[677]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-684)[[678]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-685) Numerous defendants investigated or prosecuted for violent acts and hate crimes cited his rhetoric in arguing that they were not culpable or should receive leniency.[[679]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-686)[[680]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-687) A nationwide review by [ABC News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABC_News_(United_States) "ABC News (United States)") in May 2020 identified at least 54 criminal cases, from August 2015 to April 2020, in which he was invoked in direct connection with violence or threats of violence mostly by white men and primarily against minorities.[[681]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-688) Trump's refusal to condemn the white supremacist [Proud Boys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proud_Boys "Proud Boys") during a 2020 presidential debate[[682]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-689) and his comment, "Proud Boys, stand back and stand by", were said to have led to increased recruitment for the pro-Trump group.[[683]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-690) Counterterrorism researchers described his normalization and [revisionist history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_revisionism "Historical revisionism") of the January 6 Capitol attack, and [grant of clemency to all January 6 rioters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pardon_of_January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack_defendants "Pardon of January 6 United States Capitol attack defendants"), as encouraging future political violence.[[684]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-691)[[685]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump#cite_note-692)
